div3.head: The War in China.
div3.p:
While Napoleon the Great was a captive in St. Helena, Lord Amherst touched at the island on his return from China, and paid him a visit at Longwood.
When the Ambassador had retired, the Emperor entered into a long discourse with O'Meara, upon the failure of his Lordship's mission, and the causes which led to it. In the course of his remarks he said that it would be very impolitic in the British Government to enter into a war with the Chinese.
They could easily beat them at first, he said, but they would teach them how to fight, and when they had one learned their numbers, that they would become the most formidable people upon the face of the earth.
Part of this prediction seems to becoming true.

If the first war undertaken by England against China, about twenty years ago, her operations were confined to Canton and its vicinity.
Her men-of-war easily sunk the wretched junks that attempted to oppose their advance, and her troops quite as easily dispersed the Chinese forces armed with matchlocks or bows and arrows, many of whom threw somersets and uttered terrible yells, helping, in their semi-barbarian ignorance, to frighten them from the field.
The English troops could afford to laugh at their antics, and to boast that they "shot them flying" Just as easily, a few years ago, in company with the French, they again inflicted a severe chastisement upon the same foe. But since the seat of war has been removed into the Northern provinces, they have encountered a very different kind of resistance.
No instance in history, that we know of, except the defeat at New Orleans, can compare with the defeat on the Peiho in 1859.
In the battle which took place a few months ago, the Chinese, although defeated, displayed prodigies of valor.
We doubt whether any troops in the world could have stood the destructive fire which was poured upon them from a distance so great that they could not return it, longer than they did. Nor, when it came to a hand to hand fight, did the Chinese display any want of desperate valor.
With weapons every way unequal, without discipline, and without even the stimulant of hope to keep up their spirits, they fought to the last extremity.--When at last compelled to retreat, they left the ground strewed with their own bodies and those of the enemy.

Lord Elgin, however, is advancing in the rear of a great force upon Pekin.
The Chinese have been beaten, but at the last accounts, they were ready to fight again.
It seems evident to us that they do not mean to give up their capital without a desperate resistance.--It is almost impossible, nevertheless, that they should eventually succeed.
They will be beaten, and the allies, after wading through a sea of blood, will arrive in Pekin, and dictate the law to the Emperor.
What then!
This is scarcely the beginning of what they will yet have to encounter.
They have taught the Chinese how to fight.
It is a lesson which they will not be apt to forget, and the consequences may yet be of the most serious character.
The Chinese have learned that they are superior to themselves only because they have better arms, and that, man to man, and arms equal, they have no advantage whatever over them.
They will take care to provide themselves better in future, and the catastrophe of the Peiho, where they had erected fortifications in the best and most scientific style, shew what they can do in imitating their enemies.

It would have been far better to allow the Chinese to remain in ignorance of their real strength.
The allies have found, to their cost, that a war with them is becoming every year a more serious matter.
Its costs too much to be indulged in as a mere luxury; and, in our view of the subject, it is not likely to produce any impression which will last longer than their armies remain in the country.

div3.head: Thackeray.
div3.p:
This great English satirist, who undoubtedly writes the strongest, sharpest and smartest things of any writer of his class in the language, who often expresses sentiments so noble in a style so touching that one can scarce refrain from tears of admiration of the writer and of sympathy with his subject, is nevertheless constantly illustrating in his own deportment the distinction which he so constantly points out and enforces in his lectures upon the English wits between the Author and the man. What scorching words he has for the whole race of Snobs, and yet what a snob Mr. Thackeray is!
What a beautiful description he gives of the true gentleman in his lectures on George IV.
We have never seen anything as good as his definition of a gentleman in that lecture; never anything of the kind as beautiful and eloquent as his tribute to Nelson, Collingswood, Southey and Reginald Heber; nothing more grand and impressive than his contrast between the Coronation scene of George the Fourth, and the resignation of his commission by that first of patriots and gentlemen, George Washington.And yet, how lamentably this man, who has such a noble and just appreciation of the essential qualities of a gentleman, and can describe them so admirably with his pen, fails to exemplify them in his daily life.
His affectation of superiority to his brother litterateurs, his incessant difficulties with some one or other of them, his most supremely ridiculous quarrel about his own nose, are peculiarities which no caricaturing but his own could make more ludicrous and nonsensical than they are.--Yes, the great Thackeray is the living illustration of the truth he has so often enforced, that a man may be a great critic and a great fool; that he may vividly describe heroism and virtue, but yet, like many a historian and biographer, be unable to fight the battles and imitate the virtues which he records.
Old Homer could never have rivalled the mighty deeds in arms which yet his muse has made immortal; even Demosthenes, whose patriotic eloquence roused all Greece to "conquer or die," failed himself to do either the one or the other; and Milton, who wrote so much of angles, was anything but an angel beneath his own roof.
Many of the most enthusiastic admirers of valor and self-sacrifice are themselves the most pusillanimous and selfish of human beings.
The golden head of great intellect is often, like the image recorded in the Book of David, united with a body composed of baser elements.
The Proverbs of Solomon instruct us that a fair woman without discretion is like a jewel in a swine's snout, and the same may be said of genius, when it is combined, as it often is, with ignoble passions.
All that we can do is to respect and follow the lessons of goodness and gentleness which we hear from these leachers of the people, but to beware of their example.--We must do, as the Divine Saviour of mankind instructed the Jews with reference to the Scribes, who sat in Moses' seat, observe all that they enjoin, and take heed to their words, but not imitate their works.
That which makes the vital and essential difference between mankind is not talent, nor rank, nor wealth, but the heart; and if this be found pure, believing, loyal, generous and just, there is self-respect and the respect of others here, and hereafter a dignity, power and happiness, the like of which human eye bath not seen nor human ear heard.

div3.head: Mr. Scott's letter.
div3.p:
The most remarkable letter lately published upon the great questions of the day is that of Robert E. Scott, Esq., of Fauquier, a well known and powerful Whig leader, in answer to a letter in the Enquirer. Mr. Scott is in favor of a State Convention.
His views are expressed with great seriousness and emphasis.
Although a man of peculiar personal reserve and moderation, his intellectual force is immense, and when he puts it forth in all its power it comes down like a thunderbolt.

div3.head: Hon. Caleb Cushing and the Jas. Gray.
div3.p: Mr. Cushing, in his recent speech says in reference to the hoisting of the secession flag on board the James Gray, at Charleston:

p.q: "Permit me, in the first place, to say, that whatever may have been done on board the James Gray in this respect, was done without any orders, knowledge or privity on the part of either of my brothers of myself, and that our first and only knowledge of the matter at the time was derived from the telegraphic statement as it appeared in various shapes in the newspapers of Boston."

div3.head: A woman's love for the Union.
div3.p:
A friend has communicated the following extract from a private letter written by a lady of genius, whose initials will at once be recognized as those of one of our sweetest poets as well as one of the most estimable women of America.
The letter is addressed to one of the most charming and accomplished ladies of this city, alike remarkable for her bright intellect, her patriotism, and her kind and genial disposition.
We make room for the letter and poem that accompanies it with pleasure.
The national devotion both breathe, must be appreciated by all:

div4.p:
Has not the great Mount Vernon cause, and purchase, made sisters of us all?
It ought so to be. Yet I have known you before, through that intellectual intercourse, which is sometimes better than the sight of the countenance or sound of the voice.

I have been sending Thanksgiving presents this morning, for this is an old New England puritan festival, and though you have no such observance in the Ancient Dominion, take it upon me to speed the gift of a book to you, upon the wings of the Express.
You will perceive that such of its poems as bear upon the interests of our country though written before our recent discords, breathe a spirit of harmony.

I am so grieved at our increasing disturbances and dangers.
I love Washington and his birth place, and all his children, and was early taught by my father, who shared in the wars of the Revolution, to hold our Union a sacred thing, like the Ark of the Israelites.

I pray you, is there nothing to be done?
Nothing that we women can do, without departing from our proper sphere?
Can we not throw filaments of love, like the spider's filmy thread, which the God of Peace may bless?
I enclose a little extemporaneous poem, warm from the heart, which I entrust to your judgment Please male the best use of it you can, for the sake of one who loves her whole country, and is

lg.l:
Are ye all there?
Are you all there?
Stars of my country's sky;

Are ye all there?
Are ye all there,
In your shining homes on high?
"Count us!" "Count us!" was their answer,
As they dazzled en my view,
In glorious perihelion,
Amid their fields of blue.
"I cannot count ye rightly,
There's a cloud with sable rim;
I cannot make your number out.
For my eyes with tears are dim.
O, bright and blessed Angel,
On white wing floating by,
Help me to count and not to miss
One star in my country's sky."
Then the Angel touched my eye-lids,
And touched the frowning cloud,
And its sable rim disparted,
And it fled with murky shroud.
There was no missing Pleiad,
'Mid all that sister race;
The Southern Cross shone radiant forth,
And the Pole Star Kept its place.
Then I knew it was the Angel,
Who woke the hymning strain;
That at our dear Redeemer's birth,
Flow'd out on Bethlehem's plain.
And still its echoing key tone,
My listening country held,
For all her constellated stars
The diapason swelled L. H. S.

div3.head: Exhausting the soil.
div3.p:
The New Orleans Commercial Bulletin remarks that in no country has the exhaustion of the soil been so rapid and so marked as in this country, the exhaustion prevailing alike in the Northern, the Middle, and the Southern States.
The warning voice which Humboldt addressed to England, and to point out to her the inevitable consequences of the exhaustion of her soil — where more is done, probably, to replenish a single county in that country than to replenish any one of the States of this Union--might be received with tenfold emphasis in a land from which the woods have scarcely yet been cleared away, which we are depleting and robbing every day of its elements of vitality.
In New England, says the Bulletin, the product of wheat fell off in ten years, from 1840, fifty per cent., from two million bushels to one million, and the decline has been going on since.
If it is said that this is owing to the natural barrenness of New England and the diversion of industry from agricultural to manufacturing pursuits, what shall be said of Georgia, and the comparatively new States of Kentucky, Tennessee, and Alabama, much of whose soil is naturally rich, but whose falling off in the production of wheat in the time mentioned, has been still more striking.
The yield fell off from twelve million bushels to five in a single decade.
The decrease in the great wheat-producing State of New York has been equally remarkable.
In 1848, the crop was more than thirteen million bushels, while last year it dwindled down to six.
Even the great Northwest, whose extraordinary yield last year has kept the price of flour from doubling, is undergoing the same process of depletion, and will, at no distant period, exhibit the same result of diminished crops.--Other crops might be mentioned as illustrations of the same truth.
The diminution is not referable to a reduced quantity of land sown, but to a reduction of yield per acre.--But for the quantity of new lands every year brought under cultivation, this decline of agricultural products would be exhibited in a more starting light.
This state of things the Bulletin justly considers real cause for alarm.
The process of ruin is going on steadily, and casting long, dark shadows on the future.
Before it is the Garden of Eden; behind it a desolate wilderness.
When the general productiveness of the soil is destroyed, a blight comes over every element of our national and individual wealth, over commerce and manufactures, over trade and mechanical industry, and threatens, indeed, our very existence.--This impending ruin may, and ought to be averted; but it can only be by united, vigorous and prolonged effort.
We must inaugurate a system of replenishment and compensation, of internal regeneration and recuperation, or the present exhaustive process of cultivation will burn up the earth as if a scourge of fire had passed over its surface.

div3.head: Marine Disasters for November.
div3.p:
--The number of American sea-going vessels reported as totally lost and missing during the past month amounts to thirty seven, viz.: One steamer, six ships, four barks, one brig, and twenty-five schooners.
Of these two are missing, twenty-three wrecked, four burnt, five foundered, two sunk by collisions, and one capsized.
The total value of the American craft (exclusive of cargoes) is estimated at $560,000.

div3.head: Shoes.
div3.p: --The shipments of boots and shoes from Boston to domestic markets, outside of New England, during the week ending November 28th, amounted, according to the Shoe and Leather Reporter, to 4,745 cases, of which 1,544 went to the Middle States, 1,308 to the Southern States, and 1893 to the Western States.

Attempted Insurrection in Kentucky--Fifteen Negroes and one White Man Hang.--Intelligence from Columbia, Kentucky, says a telegram, states that fifteen negroes and one white man, their leader, had been hung by the citizens of Burkesville for an attempted insurrection.
No further particulars.

div3.head: Origin of slavery in Cuba
div3.p:
--The first negro slaves directly imported into Cuba were forty negroes brought from the Cape de Verde Islands, in 1526.
They were sold for about $53 or $60 each.

div3.head: Poisoned.
div3.p:
--The overseers of the poor of Berkeley county, Va., were poisoned a few days age at a dinner at the poor-house, but have since recovered.
Two paupers are suspected.

div3.head: Two Men killed.
div3.p:
--At Randolph, in Bibb county, Ala., a young man named John Smitherman shot, with a double barrel gun, two brothers named Hill.
They were both killed.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--On Saturday morning last, the wheelwright shop of L. B. Leak, in Petersburg, was burnt, with a dwelling next door, owned by Binn Jones.
The loss is $4,000.

div3.head: Benjamin F. Powers,
div3.p: at one time an editor of the Cincinnati Gazette, died at Troy, Ohio, on Saturday, the 24th ult. He was a brother of Hiram Powers, the sculptor.
At the noon day prayer meeting in Philadelphia, on Thursday, quite a warm discussion occurred on the probabilities of disunion.

div3.head: Rees' beautiful Photographs and Pearl Ambrotypes make appropriate Holiday presents.
div3.p: --Family groups and babies beautifully taken by the aid of Rees instantaneous process, Large gilt frames and fancy cases at a very low cost, 145 Main street, over West & Johnston's Bookstore,

div3.head: Able Documents.
div3.p: --The able Letters of Hons. R. M. T. Hunter and James M. Mason, our Senators in Congress, on the subjects now agitating the country, can be had at the counting room of the "Richmond Examiner."

div3.head: Mission Chapel fair.
div3.p: --The Ladies of Centenary and other Methodist Churches of the city, will hold this week, at the Mechanics' Institute, commencing this evening, a fair and Feast, for the purpose of raising means to build a Chapel, on Marshal street, near Buchanan's Spring.

It is very many years since such an appeal to the public has been made by the Methodists of the city, and as a large number of Ornamental and Useful Articles will be offered for sale, a liberal encouragement is anticipated.
The Christmas holidays are at hand and ladies and gentlemen can supply themselves with presents for their little and large friends.
A table well supplied with Refreshments will be spread day and night for the accommodation of visitors.
All interested will please send or bring their contributions to the Hall during the day.
The managers earnestly invite the co operation of all the Methodists of the city and vicinage and solicit the attendance of the good people of the town generally.
The Fair room will be well lighted and warmed every evening, and will be open for visitors during the day. de 3--ts

div3.head: The subscribers, Stockholders of the West Point Land Company.
div3.p: and holding in the aggregate more than one-tenth of the capital stock of the said company, do hereby give notice that a general meeting of the stock holders of the said Company will be held at West Point, in the county of King William, on Wednesday, the 12th of December, 1860. Alex. Dudley,
P. P. Duval,
John Pollard.
no 8--1aw4w J. Prosser Tabb.

div3.head: Notice to Stockholders
div3.p:
An adjourned meeting of the stockholders of the Richmond and York River Railroad Company will be held at Westpoint, in the county of King William, on Wednesday, the 12th day of December next.
with the view of electing a President of the Company, and of adopting such measures of retrenchment and reform as the condition of the Company may indicate to be needful and proper.
It is all important that the meeting be a full one, and Stockholders are earnestly requested to attend in person if possible; otherwise by proxy.
se 13--2awtd A. W. Morton, Sec'y.

N. B.--A Train of cars for the accommodation of Stockholders attending the above meeting will leave the Depot of the Company on the Dock, at 9 o'clock A. M., and return in the evening.
leaving West Point at 5 o'clock, or immediately after the adjournment of the meeting.
no 30--2awtd A. W. M., Sec'y

div3.head: Religious notice.
div3.p: --A Daily Union Prayer meeting is held at the rooms of the Young Men's Christian Association in Goddin's Hall, from 12 to 1 o'clock.
Christians of all denominations, and strangers visiting the city, are cordially invited to attend.

div4.p:
On the 2d December, Mr. Ina Kennedy, in the 34th year of his age. He leaves a kind and devoted wife and four children to mourn their irreparable loss.
He was a kind husband and an indulgent father.

p.q: "The Lord giveth and the Lord taketh away; blessed be the name of the Lord"

div4.p: His funeral will take place this evening at 3 o'clock, from his late residence corner of 3d and Leigh streets. His friends are invited to attend.
Petersburg papers please copy.

On Sunday, Dec. 2nd. at 9 o'clock, of typhoid fever.
Frances A., wife of G. W. Lockwood, in the 37th year of her age.

Her funeral will take place at the First Baptist Church this (Tuesday) morning, at 11 o'clock -- The friends of the family, and those of his brothers, A. and E. K. Lockwood, are respectfully invited to attend, without further notice.

At his residence in Mecklenburg, Ben. B. Fowler, in the 31st year of his age. He was an affectionate husband and father, a kind neighbor and friend; he was respected and beloved by all who knew him, and leaves behind a devoted wife and two children, a large circle of friends and relatives to mourn their irreparable foss.

p.q: "The Lord giveth and the Lord taketh away."

New and improved edition, cap felio, half calf; price $1.50. Also, a larger edition for Cotton Plantations; price $2.00. Sent by mail, post paid
This Book is by one of the best and most systematic farmers in Virginia, and experienced farmers have expressed the opinion that those who use it will save hundreds of dollars.

We have this day commenced canvassing the city for a new Directory and we can guarantee, with our present facilities, to produce a correct and reliable guide for our business men and others.

Every advertiser is entitled to one copy of the work free of charge.
Each book will contain one of Mr. Ferslew's maps of the city.
We expect to issue in January.

New Gallery.
div3.p: (Two doors below the American Hotel.)

"A Grand Triumph." The world never knew its equal.
Barnum thrown completely in the shade.
The Prince of Wales and Creek Nation don't stand any chance Mozis Addums with his boss pistol are completely behind the times when compared with Powers' brand-new Ambrotype Gallery.
Why, gracious goodness, they take Likenesses there as big as your two hands for only Fifty Cents.

div3.head: Terrible times down South.
div3.p:
--Everybody is preparing for war. Great excitement.
The people are making ready for the battle.
South Carolina is about to secede.
But Rock's good Samaritan is still in the field.
It has relieved many poor invalids, and is prepared to give relief to many more.
It will cure Rheumatism, Neuralgia, Stiffness of Joints. &c, and all kinds of pains.
For sale by all the Druggists of Richmond and elsewhere.

Considers it his duty, in gratitude to the author, and for the benefit of Consumptive and Nervous sufferers, to publish the means used.
He will, therefore, send free, to any address, on receipt of two stamps, a copy of the work, containing every information required.

div3.p: --A notice having appeared in the Dispatch of the 30th inst., over the signature of Evan F. Ragland & Co., informing the public that I had been enjoined from using the name of James C. McCarthy & Co. in the way of endorsements or otherwise, I beg leave, also, to inform them that a Receiver having been appointed by the Court of Chancery, the Messrs.. Ragland have no longer authority to use the name of the firm in any transaction whatever.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Delinquent consumers of Water in Jefferson Ward are hereby notified that if they fail to pay their bills on or before the 5th inst., before the hour of 3 o'clock P. M., they will be dealt with according to the requirements of the following extract from the ordinance concerning the Water Works:

"By an ordinance passed by the Council May 31st, 1858," If any Water Bill remain unpaid for Thirty days next after that on which it is presented, the Auditor shall notify the Superintendent, who shall stop the Water from being used on the premises in respect to which the default exists, (and he shall not allow it to be used on those premises again until said bill in paid.) and five percent. will be added to the original amount of the bill which shall be placed in the hands of the City Collector, who is hereby authorized and required to collect the same as if it was due for city taxes.
D. J. Saunders, Jr., for
de 4--2t M. L. Stratton, Auditor.

div3.head: Book and Job Printing.
div3.p:
The undersigned would respectfully announce to his customers and the public that he is now prepared to execute, at short notice, any description of Book and Job Printing, from the smallest visiting card to the largest law book.
He is also prepared to execute, in the neatest and most fastidious manner, all kinks of Fancy Printing, in various colors-- Carmine.
Pink, Purple, Bronze, Red, Brown Yellow, Green — in short, any color that may be desired, and as many jobs as any person may wish, in this branch of his business, he defies competition by any printer in the city.
All he asks is a trial Satisfaction guaranteed.
George W. Gary.

div3.head: Virginia City, on Norfolk harbor
div3.p:

Lots now only $60--$145 in monthly payments of $5--the greatest portion of the cigar receipts to be appropriated for manufacturing purposes. for which a company has been chartered, (capital, $500,000; shares, $500 each,) in which all friends of manufacturing industry in this locality are invited to participate.
Another portion of the receipts for lots to be appropriated for street and other public improvements.
For particulars, and subscription for Lots or Manufacturing Stocks apply to Office Virginia City Company, 21 Main st., Norfolk, Va. Wm.Schmoele, Pres't.

div3.head: Notice to Tax Payers.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to an ordinance passed 11th January, 1855, I will attend at the Collector's Office.
in the City Hall, from the 15th to the 31st December, inclusive, to receive the remaining half of taxes from such persons as are entitled to a deduction of 10 percent, by having previously paid the first half in June last, in accordance with said ordinance.
Julius A. Hobson. C. C. R.

N. B.--It will be seen from the above that the Collector is required to attend at the Office from the 15th to the 31st of the month to receive taxes remaining due from June last.
Before the January term of the Hustings Court, he is required, by ordinance, to advertise delinquent real estate to be sold for non-payment of taxes.
Persons who have not done so will see the necessity of calling and paying these taxes as it will be impossible for the Collector to call on them before he advertises.
de 1--1m J. A. H. C. C. R.

div3.head: By the Governor
div3.p: --A Proclamation.--Whereas, It appears by the return received from the Commissioners appointed by this Commonwealth to superintend the election of Electors of President and Vice President of the United States, that a majority of the votes in said election was given for.
Thos. Bruce, of Halifax.
Marmaduke Johnson, of Richmond City.
Lemuel J. Bowden, of Williamsburg.
J. J. Jackson, Jr., of Wood.
F. T. Anderson of Rockbridge.
. H. Shackleford of Fauquier.
A. B. Caldwell, of Ohio.
L. H. Chandler, of Norfolk City.
Joseph Christian, of Middlesex,
William Lamb, of Norfolk City,
John R. Edmunds, of Halifax.
James Lyons, of Richmond City,
Richard A. Claybrook, of Northumberland,
W. H. Anthony. of Botetourt,
J. W. Massie, of Rockbridge,

Therefore, I. John Letcher, Governor, do hereby make proclamation that the said persons have been duly elected Electors for and on behalf of the Commonwealth of Virginia, to vote for a President and Vice President of the United States
The Electors are required by law to meet at the Capitol, in the city of Richmond, on the first Wednesday in December next being the 30th day of the month, by ten o'clock in the morning.

Given under my hand, as Governor, and under the Less Seal of the Commonwealth, at Richmond, this 30th day of November, 1860.
John Letcher.
By the Governor:
no 30--dtd Sec of the Commonwealth.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 18, Number 133, page 3.

div3.head:
[from our Special correspondent]
affairs at Washington.

argument.p: the President and secession — Seward Yielding, but Greeley Valiant — Another rumored &c.

div4.p: --The President's plan South Carolina to postpone secession on the 4th of March next will hardly avail.-- As South Carolina member said to me this evening, "We have spiked that gun."

Senator Seward is willing to grant the South Almost anything, but the Tribune of this morning says, "Let the winds howl on; the free States will not surrender their principles on account of threatened disunion." Greeley's own article states the case, but takes no decided ground, so there is no day light yet.

All that money, beauty, place and power, can do, will be brought to bear in favor of Union.
We shall see Southerners, heretofore fiery, backing down.

Messrs Cobb, Thompson, Jeff, Davis, and Fitzpatrick of Alabama, have, it is rumored, yielded to the President's pious appeal for staving off secession.
If so, the South will be paralyzed, and the Union saved for a time.--Mississippi is reported fishy.
Still, it is believed that six States will be out of the Union before thirty days. Z.

argument.p: meeting in Charlottesville — speeches by Messrs. Massie and others — Nomination for the Legislature, &c.

div4.p:
--A0t a large assemblage of men of all parties, held here today.
(Court day,) resolutions were unanimously and enthusiastically adopted, against coercion in any event; in favor of the equality of the States above the Federal Union; against the agitation of slavery; demanding a final settlement now of all difficulties, or a dissolution of the Union; believing a State Convention absolutely necessary; against the reopening of the African slave trade; calling for a full deliberation among the people of all the States, a conference of all the Southern States recommended, and separate action deprived; also, favoring a National Convention.
The resolutions were sustained in able speeches by the leaders of all parties, among the most prominent of whom were Messrs. Massie, Southard, Randolph, Leake, Wood, Gordon, and Watson.
Thomas Wood, a States-Rights Whig, was unanimously nominated for the Legislature.

--Among the various prepositions for quieting the present political troubles, is that so much of the President's Message as treats of them be referred in the House to a select committee of members from all the States, to bring forward some compromise.

Many who formerly believed that South Carolina only will secede, are now satisfied from assurances from those representing Georgia, Alabama and Mississippi, that these States, too, will make common cause with South Carolina.
There appears to be nothing which gives conservative men any hope for a continuance of the Union.

The Supreme Court of the United States met to-day.
Judge Taney and all the assistant Judges but Wayne, were present.
They subsequently personally waited upon and paid their respects to President Buchanan.
The members practicing at the Supreme Court Bar held a meeting and passed resolutions of respect to the memory of Judge Daniel.

The Message will be sent to Congress tomorrow.
Advance copies will not be sent South beyond Richmond.
The Treasury Department paid applying members only about 25 per ct, on the amount them for mileage.
--P. M.--The projected meeting of Union Senators and members for this evening, was indefinitely postponed at the suggestion of Senator Crittenden.

div3.head: [Second Dispatch]
div3.p:
Several Southern delegations are in secret consultation to-night.
Their object seems to be to secure the co-operation of the border slave States to the secession movement.

While some Republicans affect to believe South Carolina only will secede, others are beginning to be alarmed.
Even Sumner privately said to-day there was danger of secession spreading.
The President's Message will offend the South by positive condemnation of secession, and offend the North by opposing the Personal Liberty bills.
Parties claiming to be well posted, say he (the President) will recommend the General Convention view of adjustment of the difficulties.
It is evident the Administration fears trouble in endeavoring to execute the Federal laws.

Notwithstanding there was an appearance of studied courtesy, even cordiality, to-day, between members from the extreme sections of the Union, yet a close observer could not fail to perceive occasional flashes of indignation on the part of those from the Cotton States, dreading the coming storm.

div4.p: --In the Georgia Legislature to-day, Mr. Sprayberry, of Catoosa, moved an amendment to the Retaliatory bill, as follows,

And whereas, a compact broken by one party is no longer binding, politically, socially, legally or morally upon other parties to it; and whereas, in the opinion of this General Assembly, the States considerate in it have grossly violated the compact of Union by refusing to deliver up fugitives: Been enacted that the State of Georgia withdraw its confederated faith from all States which interpose obstacles to the recovery of our rights under the Constitution.
And be it hereby further enacted and decreed, that all officers of this State, civil and military, who have taken the oath to support the Constitution of the United States, be hereby relieved and absolved from the obligations of such oaths, in all cases in the Courts of this State, where States or citizens of States who refuse our constitutional are parties, or otherwise concerned.

Mr. Sprayberry's amendment was lost — ayes 96, noes 89.
The Retaliatory bill, however, passed the House.

--A large secession meeting was held here last night.
John Bragg, Judge Dargan, Geo. O. Ketchum and H. G. Humphreys were unanimously nominated as delegates to the State Convention.

--Mr. Holt, of Muskogee, submitted a preamble and resolutions as the special order for Tuesday.
The resolutions propose a conference of the Southern States at Atlanta on the 20th of February, to counsel and advise as to the mode and manner of resistance to the existing exigency of affairs.
The preamble takes strong grounds in favor of having all sectional questions finally settled, and objects to separate action.

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p:
--Senate--In the Senate, to-day, after assembling, nothing was done save the appointment of a committee to wait on the President, and inform him that the body was in session and ready for business.
It adjourned before 1 o'clock.
Nearly all the Senators were in their seats, and good feeling prevailed.
House.--A joint committee was appointed to wait on the President and apprise him of the organization of the House.

About an hour was spent in selecting seats, which was marked by hilarity and good humor.
At 1½ o'clock the House adjourned.
About 200 members were present, including all the South Carolina delegates except Hon. Porcher Miles.
The galleries were crowded to overflowing.
The Message will be sent in at noon to-morrow

div3.head: A "John Brown" meeting broken up in Boston.
div3.p:
--A John Brown meeting, called by the abolitionists, assembled in the Maconic Temple to-day.
The Temple was taken possession of by the Union men, who chose Richard Sullivan Fay, Chairman, and passed resolutions denouncing John Brown, justifying his execution and landing Virginia.
Fred Douglas, Redpath, Frank Sanborn, and other notorious abolitionists, vainly endeavored to make themselves heard.
Much confusion prevailed, and the police were called, and the hall was cleared and closed by order of the Mayor.

div3.head: Marine Disasters.
div3.p:

U. S. surveying schooner Crawford arrived here with loss of both anchors and foremast sprung.
She will be taken to the navy-yard for repairs.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p: --Ran away on Saturday, the 3d inst, from the employment of Dr. John B. Eastham, of Louisa county, a Negro man, named Ralph, belonging to the estate of Jesse Perkins, dec'd.

Ralph is about twenty-two years of age black, about five feet five inches high; one of his front teeth is out, and the rest are very broad and white.
No peculiar mark about him is remembered, but we think he has a scar between his fore-finger and thumb on one of his hands — can't say which.
He, it is said, can write a good hand and is probably making his way to a free State.

The above reward will be paid for his apprehension in the State and delivery to us, or being placed in a jail so that we get him; or, if taken out of the State and delivered to us, or placed in a jail in this State, so that we get him, a reward of $10 will be paid.
Wm. Crawford.
John R. Quarles,
Frank T. West,
Ex'ors of Jesse Perkins, dec'd.
Trevillian's Depot, Louisa co., no 14--ts

Nov. 12th 1860.
no 14--ts

div3.head: Seventy-Five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $7500 for the apprehension of my Negro Girl, Peggy, who absconded about three weeks ago. She is a low, thick set mulatto, with short curly hair, and is about sixteen years old. Her dress cannot be described, as she has been seen several times in this city since she left, and had on a different dress each time.

div3.head: The Singer Sewing Machines.
div3.p:
--The marked and ever extended popularity of Singer's Sewing Machines, both in America and Europe, is such as best to establish their superiority over all others in the market.
Sewing Machines, so called, may be bought, it is true, for a smaller amount of dollars, but it is mistaken economy to invest anything in a worthless or unreliable article, and those who will do so must abide the consequences.
Singer's New Family Machines
In order to place the very best Family Machines in the world within the reach of all, we have reduced our Letter A, or transverse Shuttle Machines, beautifully ornamented, to Fifty Dollars.
Singer's No. 1 and 2 Standard Shuttle Machines.

Both of very general application and capacity, and popular both in the family and the manufactory.
Prices reduced respectively from $135 and $150 to $90 and $100.
Singer's No. 3 Standard Shuttle Machine.

For carriage-makers and heavy leather work.
Price, complete, $125

Also, to complete the list, an entirely new article, unequaled for manufacturing purposes, noiseless, rapid, and capable of any kind of work.
Price, including iron stand and drawers, $110, cheaper at that, in view of its value, than the machines of any other maker as a gift.

All of Singer's Machines make the interlocked stitch with two threads, which is the best stitch known.
Every person desiring to procure full and reliable information about Sewing Machines, their sizes, prices, working capacities, and the best method of purchasing, can obtain it by sending for a copy of "I. M. Singer & Co.'s Gazette," which is a beautiful pictorial paper, entirely devoted to the subject.
It will be supplied gratis.

Needles, Thread, Cottons Silk, and all necessary articles used with Sewing Machines, kept constantly on hand for sale.
Also, a practical machinist, who is ever ready to attend on our customers, if required.

I. M. Singer & Co.'S office being conducted on the most thorough business principles, by an entirely new set of hands, we feel confident of doing our share of the business, as we have always done heretofore.

div3.head: Virginia Steam Sugar Refinery.
div3.p: The proprietor takes pleasure in announcing to the public that the
Virginia Steam Sugar Refinery is now in full and regular operation, and has capacity sufficient for a very large demand.
His arm will be to render satisfaction to all of his customers, and he trusts that he will meet with a liberal patronage from the merchants of the Southern States.

The Refinery is located immediately on the wharf at Rocketts, and is conveniently situated for shipments in every direction.
For the present only white and yellow Coffee Sugars will be made, and if the enterprise meets with that success the proprietor hopes to deserve, he will, in the Spring, enlarge the buildings, put on additional machinery, and manufacture Loaf and Crushed Sugars.

Being governed in his sales by the New York prices, he hopes the merchants of his own State and other Southern States will patronise him liberally, and he guarantees that his Sugars are equal to similar Sugars manufactured North.
Orders will be received for 10 bbls. Sugar and 5 bbls Syrup and upwards.
Sugars and Syrup delivered to any store in the city, or at any of the Railroad Depots, Wharves, or on Canal Boats, free of charge.

Orders by mail or telegraph promptly attended to at selling prices of the day on which they are received, unless limited.
Samples of each day's refining will be exhibited at the office, No. 42 Main street, under the St. Charles Hotel.
Chas. Y. Morriss,
Proprietor of the Va. Steam Sugar Refinery.
no 5--1mcw2t

div3.p: Chas. H. Langley,

Would inform the public that he is sole agent for the sale of
Hawley's improved Cylinder Gas
Burners,

and is prepared to put them up at the shortest notice, and on the most reasonable terms.
The advantages of these Burners are: To prevent blowing and waste of gas, to give a more clear and uniform light, to regulate the quantity consumed with the full head turned on to any desired amount, and thus to save at least twenty-five per cent, over the ordinary Burners.

Mr. J. F. Brown, in charge of the Washington City Gas Works, has certified that they are unhesitatingly the best Burners he has seen during his connection of twelve years with those works; and the Superintendent of the Richmond Gas Works asserts that he has tried them, and that they save at least twenty per cent, over other Burners.

div3.p: Trustee's sale of Thirty-three Acres of Land on the Williamsburg Stage Road, in Henrico County.--By virtue of a deed of trust from Elvira C. Garrett, dated the 28th day of February, 1860, and of record in the Clerk's Office of Henrico County Court, (D. B 74, P. 185.,) I shall, at the request of the beneficiary, proceed to sell upon the premises on Friday the 14th day of December, 1860, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) commencing at 12 o'clock M, the property described in said deed, as follows; "All that certain piece or parcel of land lying and being in the county of Henrico, on the north side of the Williamsburg Stage Road, and containing thirty-three Acres, more or less, adjoining the lands of Samuel Bradley's children Polly Shum, William F. Hord, and others, and being the same real estate conveyed to said Elvira C. Garrett by Charles Hagan trustee for Margaret Dobbins, and others, by deed bearing date 28th February, 1860, and recorded as above."

Terms--Enough in cash to defray the expenses of sale and a bond for $200, with interest from December 1st, 1860 till paid; the remainder upon such terms as may be agreed upon on the day of sale.
John J. Fallen, Trustee.

the place to buy cheap Goods is certainly at No. 25 Main street, where can be found Bosoms at 6c; Hoop Skirts at 25c; Flannel at 16 2/3 and 20c; best Ladies Bootees at $1 and $1,25; Plain and Figured Mouslaines at 12 ½c; Men's and Ladies' Collars at 6; Merinos at 20, and bargains in almost all kinds of Dry Goods.
Don't forget the place, at
Wertheimer & Lowenberg's,
de 1--1m No. 25 Main street.

--230 Broad street.

My stock of Window Shades being very large.
I am determined to run them off cheaper than ever.
The following is my list of prices:--Dark Landscapes, 31 cents, worth 75; Plain Gold Shades, 75 cents, with fixtures complete; Gold, with Centre $1, worth at least $3; Gold and Velvet, $1.50, worth $4; beautiful Bouquets, 75 cents, cheap at $1.50; splendid Vase Shades, 90 cents can't be bought elsewhere for $2; Gothic style, Dry Landscapes, Pleasure and Hunting Scenes, in endless variety; German, English and American Oil Cloths, all widths, very cheap; Table and Stand Covers; Hearth Rugs, very low and all wool; Carpeting only 50 cents, a great bargain; 150 large gilt framed Parlor Pictures, rich scenery, at the astonishing low price of $2, worth $6; also, a large line of Dry Goods, cheap for cash.
Call soon at the established cheap Dry Goods and Window Shade Store of M. Golden, 230 Broad street.

P.S.--I keep no traveling agents.
se 19--3m

--Owing to the tightness of money matters, and the critical State of the country, we will offer our entire stock of goods at such reduced prices as to suit the most economical ones.
Tarlatans, 16 cents a yard; Cloaks, $4 and $5; Linen Cambric Hdkfs, at 8, 10 and 12 cents--some very superior at 16 cents, admitted by everybody to be worth 25 cents; Cambric Bands, 25 cents; Bonnet Velvets, $1.50; Ladies' White Cotton Hose extra heavy, at 12 ½ cts., Rich Crochet Fringes at $1.50 and higher prices; Dress Trimmings, a great reduction made; Head Dresses. Bleached Cottons, Black Silks and Corsets, at low prices, and so many other articles.
The ladies may rest assured that the goods must be sold at some prices, as the whole and entire stock will be closed out. So don't delay, but go to the right store, which is E. Goldsmit.
176 Broad street.

div3.head: Uncurrent money, received at par.
div3.p:
--North and South Carolina Bank notes uncurrent Virginia money, notes of the Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, Louisiana, Kentucky and all other solvent Banks in the United States will be received at my Store, at their par value, without discount, for Dry Goods of every description, at prices reduced to suit the present hard times Purchasers who have not furnished themselves with their Fall and Winter Dry Goods, will find this a rare opportunity of doing so, on very favorable terms.
The whole of my valuable stock will be offered at prices Regardless of cost, for cash only.
Call soon at the Bargain Emporium of Alfred Moses,

div3.head: Dry Goods at reduced prices.
div3.p:
--Dry Goods at reduced prices — To be prepared in the best manner possible for whatever may be the result of the present political excitement, we offer our entire stock of Goods at reduced prices.
The stock is large and better than it has ever been before at this season.
Carpets, Cloaks, Dress Silks, Poplins, Ripps, Merinoes, Mouselaines, Servants' Clothing of all kinds; in short, every variety of Dry Goods at very reduced prices.
Our customers may expect bargains in every style of Goods, as they must be sold before the close of the season.
Chiles & Chenery.

div3.head: At prime cost, for cash.
div3.p:
--Positively to close business Store for Rent.--With a view to raise money to meet our maturing obligations and to discontinue the Dry Goods business, we offer our entire stock of Staple and Fancy Dry Goods at and under cost for cash, until the 10th day of December when the whole stock will be offered at auction and the sale continued from day to day, until sold.
The terms of the auction will be duly notified.
Until that time, our friends who will give us a call, can get useful family goods at their own prices.
Chas. A. Gwatkin,
8th and Main street, North side.
N. B.--The store is for rent.

div3.head: Ladies' Wear.
div3.p:
--Ladies' Merino Vests and Drawer; Ladies' Silk Vests and Drawers; Ladies' Linen Chemise; Ladies' Linen Yokes and Sleeves; Ladies' Imperial Skirts; Ladies' Lace Setts, Collars and Sleeves; Ladies' Breakfast Setts and Collars; Ladies' white and black Crape Setts; Ladies' Embroidered and Lace Handkerchiefs; Cambric and Linen Edges and Inserting; Gloves and Hosiery in all styles; Children's Hosiery, a full assortment; Goods for families, in every variety.
A full stock at 99 Main st
Christian & Lathrop.

--No. 41 Main St. Call and see the cheap Shirt Bosoms; nice Marseilles Bosoms for a ninepence; nice Marseilles Bosoms, Collar, and Cuffs, a fine article, at only 25 cents the set, usual price 50 cents; fine Linen Bosoms in sets, with Collars and Cuffs, very cheap.
Call and see at
Ezekiel's Cheap Store, No. 41 Main st.

div3.head: Just the thing for the Ladies
div3.p:
--Quilted Skirts.--Two hundred Quilted Skirts of various styles, suited for the present season, to be run off cheap.
Call and see; you'll be sure to buy one at
Ezekiel's Cheap Store, 41 Main st.

go to Levy's, and purchase some of the following articles.
They are all cheap and much less than can be had elsewhere.
Yard wide Unbleached Cotton at 8 ½ cts., worth 10; extra Irish Linen at 50 cts., well worth 75; Cross Plaid Linen Bosoms at 50 cts, worth 75 and various other Goods; all of which will be sold at the lowest cash prices.

div3.head: Superfine Marseilles Bosoms.
div3.p: --Bosoms, Collars and Cuffs of superfine Marseilles, duly 25 cts, the set; white and colored Marseilles Bosoms, only a ninepence each; superfine Linen Bosoms, very cheap, at
Ezekiel's Cheap Store,

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.
div3.p:
large sale of Cows.--The subscribers, intending to discontinue the Dairy business, in which they have been engaged for the past twelve months, will offer for sale, to the highest bidder, on Thursday, December 6th, their entire Herd of Cows.
Many of them are fine animals, and of "good blood"--forward with calf.
Sale at 12 o'clock, at the stables of Jacob S. Atlee, Esq.,(Powhatan Warehouses Rocketts,)
Terms--Under $50, cash; over that amount, four months credit, for approved, endorsed, negotiable paper.
Several Horses will be added to the above sale.
J. E. Williams,
Wm. L. Hill.

div3.head: Trustee's sale of House and Lot on Duval street.
div3.p:
--Under the provision of a trust deed executed by L. Q. Landrum and wife, dated April 1st, 1859, to the late Richard J. Blunt, to secure a debt of $350, with interest.
I shall proceed to sell, on the premises, on Tuesday, 11th December, 1860, at 4 o'clock P.M., that Land, with a Building thereon, lying on the south side of Duval street, nearly opposite the Duval street Church, and fronting 21 feet on said Duval street. The lot is part of No. 11, in Duval & Pleasants' Plan.

Terms.--Cash, to satisfy expenses of sale and debt secured by trust deed; for the balance, on a credit of six months, purchaser executing his negotiable note, interest added, and title retained until credit instalment is paid.
John A. Hutcheson,
Sheriff of Henrico county, and as such Administrator of Richard J. Blunt
Sale by Goddin & Apperson, Aucts. de 1

div3.head: Commissioners' sale of real estate in the Town of Fulton near to Rocketts.
div3.p:
--As Commissioners of the Circuit Court of Henrico, appointed by a decree entered on the 1st November, 1860 in the case of Enroughty and wife against Bergman, &c, we shall sell at public auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 10th December, 1860, at 3 ½ o'clock P.M., (if fair; if not, the first fair day,) the real estate located as above, of which the late Fred. Bergman died seized, and now occupied by his widow.
There are several beautiful building lots, and an excellent new Brick Tenement, used as a Store and Dwelling, and considered an excellent stand for business.

Terms.--Enough in cash to defray the expenses of sale and costs of suit; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, satisfactorily endorsed, and title retained till the further order of the Court.
P. H Aylett, Comr's.
Henry G. Cannon, Comr's.
no 27 Johnson H Sands, Comr's.

div3.head: By Ro. B. Lyne, Auct
div3.p:
Valuable Market Farm, Five miles below Richmond, on the Charles City Road, containing 45 Acres, for sale at public Auction.--At the request of Mr. Theodore Hoppe, I shall sell at public auction, on the 10th day of December, at the hour of 11 o'clock, upon the premises, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) that valuable small Farm situated as described above, containing 45 acres, and adjoins the lands of Ro, Farrar and others; about half cleared; the balance woods.
The cleared land is well adapted to the growth of the usual crops, especially vegetables.--The improvements are sufficient for the accommodation of a mod rate sized family.
There is a pump of excellent water in the yard.
The location is healthy and society good.
Immediately after the sale of the farm, will be sold all the Stock, Plantation Utensils, crop of Corn Fodder, &c
Mr. Hopp, laying on the premises, will take pleasure in showing it to any one wishing to purchase.
Terms--Made known on day of sale.
no 23--dtds Ro. B. Lyne, Auct,

Executor's sale of A Valuable Farm in Henrico County, 12 miles below the City of Richmond, on the New Charles City Road, containing about 500 Acres of Land, together with the stock of Horses, (several of which are young and very Valuable,) Cows Hogs, Plantation Utensils, Crops of Corn, Shucks, Fodder, Scrawl, &c., at Auction-- I will as the Executor of John Brackett deceased, sell on Tuesday, the 18th of December, 1860 at his late residence, at the hour of 11 o'clock, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) that valuable Farm upon which the said Brackett resided at the time of his death, situated as described above, containing about 500 acres of land, half cleared, a portion of which is meadow, very rich and productive.
The balance of the land is well set, in pine and oak. The improvements consist of a framed dwelling, containing 7 or 8 rooms; kitchen, negro quarters, barn, stable, carriage house, &c. The location is considered very healthy and society good, convenient to churches and mills.
And immediately after the sale of the Farm, will be sold the stock of Horses, Cows, Hogs, Plantation Utensils a Carriage and Harness, (nearly new,) House-hold and Kitchen Furniture, crops of Corn, Shucks, Fodder Straw &c

Terms of Sale,--For the land, one third cash; balance upon a credit of one, two and three years, to bear interest from day of sale, which is to be paid semi-annually.
For personal property, all sums of twenty dollars and under, cash; sums over twenty dollars, six months credit, for approved paper, to be given before property is delivered.
William Brackett,
Ex'or of John Brackett, deceased.
Sale conducted by Ro B Lyne, Auct [no 15--td]

div3.head: By Thomas Pannill, Auct'r,
div3.p: the Bulletin Newspaper FORSALE.--By virtue of deeds of trust to us from Dr. Wm. H. I. Anson, and by request of parties interested, we shall proceed to sell at public auction, in front of the Merchants' Exchange, in Petersburg, on Saturday, the 8th day of December, 1860 at 12 o'clock M., the above named Valuable Newspaper, published in this city, together with the "good will" of the same and all its Types, Presses, Furniture and Fixtures, and one Steam Engine.--The types, &c, are new. The celebrity of the Bulletin, as a leading and influential political journal, and its extensive circulation, together with the fact that it is the only Democratic paper published in this Congressional district, and with a single exception the only one in South-Side Virginia, make it one of the most desirable newspapers published in the state.
The Bulletin may be purchased privately at any time before the day of sale.

Terms--Enough in cash to pay expenses of sale, and for the balance, a credit of 6, 12, 18 and 24 months, interest added, for negotiable notes, satisfactorily endorsed, and a deed of trust, if required, on the property.
W. L. Watkins, Trustees.
Chas. S. Stringfellow, Trustees.
T. Pannill, Auct'r. no 29--3t

div3.head: Sixty-six Negroes, and a large amount of other Personal property, for sale.
div3.p: --By virtue of a deed of trust executed to the subscribers by Wm. J. Watkins, of Charlotte county, they will proceed, on Tuesday, the 18th day of December next, (if fair; if not, on the next fair day thereafter,) at his residence five miles from Keysville, on the Richmond and Danville Railroad, to make sale of the stock, Crops, Farming Implements, Household and Kitchen Furniture, lately owned by him, consisting of 30 head valuable well broke Horses and Mules; about 60 head of Cattle, including Oxen and Milch Cows; 60 head Hogs and 20 head Sheep; also, a number of Carts and Wagons; a Carriage and Buggy; a very superior seven octave Piano, and such other articles of Furniture as are usually found in a gentleman's house.

They will also, on Wednesday, the 19th December next, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) sell at the same place, at public auction, Sixty-six Valuable and likely Negroes including Men, Women and Children among them three practiced Engineers, capable of managing and running a steam-engine and circular saw.

Terms.--For all sums under $20, cash; for all sums over that amount, a credit of six months will be given, taking from the purchasers bonds, with approved security, bearing interest from the date.
Thos Watkins, Trustees.
Mount Laurel, Halifax, Va.; Trustees.
Richard V. Gaines Trustees.
Drake's Branch, Charlotte, Va; Trustees.

div3.head: Sale of stock, Crops, Farming Implements, &c.
div3.p:
--On Wednesday, the 5th day of December next, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) will be sold, at Kennon's, the late residence of John H Steger, dec'd, in the county of Amelia, all the stock of Horses, Cattle, Sheep and Hogs; also, the crops of Tobacco, Corn, Oats and Fodder, and all the Farming Implements, of every description.
The sale will commence at 11 o'clock A.M., and continue from day to day until completed.
Terms.--For all sums of $20 and under, cash will be required; for sums over $20, six months credit will be given, the purchaser giving bond with approved security.
By order of the Executor.
P.S.--At the same time and place, the heirs of John H. Steges, dec'd, will offer for sale the valuable adjoining Farm, known as Bellevue, containing about 1,000 acres. no 23--dtd

div3.head: Auction sale of Personal property, at Woodland, New Kent County, Va
div3.p:
--On Wednesday 5th day of December at 11 o'clock A. M. (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) I will, as executor of Chas. Pearson deceased proceed to sell all the Personal property on the place consisting of Horses, Cattle, Sheep, Hogs, Corn, Fodder, Shucks, Plantation Utensils, Household and Kitchen Furniture.
Also, a Two-Horse Carriage, Ox Cart, Market Cart and Wagon.
Terms.--All sums under $10, cash; over that amount 6 months credit for approved bonds.
John P. Pearson, Ex'r.
no 16--3t&D3d,4th, 5th

--A permanent solution of Protoxide of Iron.--The Protoxide of Iron is a most valuable form of iron for all diseases in which iron is necessary, but is very difficult to be maintained in that state.
In the Peruvian Syrup the difficulty has been overcome, and physicians, &c, can rely on having the preparation in its most efficient form.
For sale by
A. Bodeker & Co.,
Apothecaries, No. 10 Main street.

div3.p:

div3.head: By Alex Nott, Auct'r.
div3.p: Furniture, Dry Goods, Groceries, &c.--Will be sold at auction, at any store, corner of Main and 15th sts. on Tuesday Morning, the 4th day of December, commencing at 10 o'clock, a general assortment of Furniture, Carpets, Stoves, &c
Dry Goods.--Hoop Skirts, Net Shirts, Drawers, Jackets, Coats, Pants, Vests, Yarn and Cotton Socks, &c.
Also, lot of Furs, Victorines, Capes, Cuffs and Mutts.
Groceries.--Whiskey, Brandy, Manufactured, Tobacco, Irish Potatoes, Glassware, Cigars, &c. de 3 Alex'r Nott, Auct

div3.head: Sale of Personal property, in the County of Amelia.
div3.p:
--On Tuesday, the 4th day of December next.
I shall offer for sale, at auction, on the farm of the late Col. Jos. Bragg situated two miles from Amelia Court House, all the Personal property, including Horses, Mules, Oxen, Milch Cows, Hogs, Sheep, Corn, Oats, Fodder, Wagons, Carts, Threshing Machine, Fan Mill, and other Farming Implements.

Terms.--Under $50, cash; $50 and over, six months credit, without interest, if punctually paid at maturity, otherwise interest will be charged from day of sale, for which bonds, with satisfactory security, will be required.
Jos R. Dunn.
no 28--3t,Wf&M Ex'or of Jos. Bragg, dec'd.

div3.head: Trustee's sale of Steam Engine and Saw-Mill.
div3.p:
--As trustee in a certain deed from Booth & Liggon, and of record in Hanover Court-House, and likewise recorded in New Kent County Court House, by request of the beneficiaries in said deed, I shall offer for sale, on Tuesday, 4th of December, 1860, without reserve, for cash, one-half of said Steam Engine and Saw-Mill, including all fixtures thereto belonging, upon the premises, namely; the lands of Reuben L. Walker, in New Kent county, about half a mile from the York River Railroad.
Sale to commence at 12 o'clock.
Robert W. Robinson, Trustee.
no 19--tD4

div3.head: By J. H. Digges, Auct'r.
div3.p:
fine Gold and Silver Watches, Jewelry, Fancy Goods, &c.--Will be sold at auction, every night this week, at Auction Room 86 Main street. Also, a lot of Blankets Undershirts, Drawers fine Table Cutlery, Plated Spoons, Forks, &c., &c. Sale will commence at 7 o'clock, P. M. J. H. Digges.
Auct

D. F. Booth, Salesman.
oc 23--ts

div3.head: Notice
div3.p: --to the Creditors of Daniel Hagerty and of Hagerty A Starke.--Daniel Hagerty having assumed by contract, the payment of the debts of the late firm of Hagerty & Starke, and being entitled under the same contract to all the assets of the late concern, including debts due it, and said Haggerty having by deed dated the 21st November, 1860 recorded on the same day in the Clerk's Office of the Hustings Court for the city of Richmond, conveyed his stock of goods, and all his property and assets of ever description, real and personal, to the undersigned, in trust, for the benefit of his creditors and the creditors of Haggerty & Starke, according to certain classes there in arranged; and said deed also providing, among other things, that no creditor shall be entitled to any benefit therefrom unless he assents to the terms of the said dec'd by signing the same within thirty days from its date--

Notice is hereby given to all persons indebted to the said Haggerty, or to the said firm, to settle immediately with the undersigned, and to persons having claims under the terms of said deed, to present the same.
And notice is also given that said deed will remain in the Clerk's Office of the Court of Hustings the prescribed time, to be signed by such creditors as are willing to accept the terms of the same.
V. Bargamin,
no 24--ts Trustee.

div3.head:
Planing Machines and Steam
Engines
made upon Southern soil.
div3.p: the Union Manufacturing Co.,

Are now ready to furnish the celebrated Wood worth Planing Machines, which require no other recommendation than their already established reputation; and also Stationary Steam Engines, of from 25 to 100 horse power, which they will build at a less price per horse power than they can be furnished by any Northern establishment

These Machines are built under the personal supervision of John H Lester, Lester . Esq., formerly of Brooklyn, N. Y., who, as a manufacture, is well and widely known, and they are warranted to give satisfaction.
of ., 231 Main street,
Richmond, Virginia.
Send for a Descriptive Pamphlet no 23--ts

div3.head:
Richmond Type Foundry,
located in the Law Building,
on Franklin street.
div3.p:
The proprietors of the above establishment beg leave to say that they are prepared to execute any order, for Newspaper, Book or Job Printing Offices, and are now manufacturing, on the spot, a new dress for the Richmond Dispatch.
In soliciting the patronage of the South we guarantee to furnish as good an article as can be had North, and at New York prices.
We have extensive business connections with nearly all the type foundries in the United States, and are, therefore, enabled to furnish Type of other manufacturers when required.

We desire every newspaper in the South to copy this advertisement for one month sending us one copy of the paper, and they will receive their pay by purchasing of us five times the amount of their bill for such advertisement.
Walker & Pelouze,
no 29--1m Richmond, Va.

to the Creditors of the estate of Lucy Coleman, Dec'd. and all others Concerned.--You are hereby notified that at the request of Mr. George A. Pearch, executor of the said Lucy Coleman, dec'd, I have appointed the 8th day of December next, at my office, for receiving proof of debts or demands against the said decedent or her estate, at which time and place you are required to stand.
Given under my hand, as Commissioner in Chancery of the County Court of Henrico County, the day and year first aforesaid.
no 29--td J. H. Sands

div3.head: Five Dollars reward,
div3.p:
--Escaped from the old jail of Henrico county, on the night of the 14th inst., Joseph Eubank, a white man convicted by the County Court of Henrico county of a misdemeanor, and sentenced to six months imprisonment.
The said Eubank is about 23 years old, 5 feet 10 inches high, with a very full black beard, covering nearly his whole face.
He was dressed in a black frock coat grey pants, and slouched white hat. Whoever will return the said Eubank to the jail of said county, will receive the above reward.
no 19--ts John A. Hutcheson, S. H. C

div3.head:
Spotswood House,
Richmond, Va.
div3.p: This new Hotel, at the corner of Main and 8th streets, just finished and elegantly furnished, is now open for the accommodation of guests.
The location is the best in the city, and every effort will be made to please the patrons of the House.
I have secured the services of Mr. T. W. Hoenniger, late of the Everett House, New York.
no 5--1y Joseph H. Crenshaw.

div3.head: Beautiful and Central Building Lots, Corner Broad and Capitol and 10th sts. For Rent or sale
div3.p:
--These building lots, fronting 54 feet on Capitol and Broad streets respectively, and 140 feet on 10th street are, for private or public purposes unequalled by any other in the city.
Surrounded by streets on three sides, and fronting the Capital Square, they present race attractions.
They will be rented on liberal terms or sold on a long credit.
no 19--ts J. B. Watkins, 159 Main st.

div3.head: Selling off.
div3.p:
--The stock of Planished, Japanned and Plain Tinware, Gas Fixtures, Stoves, &c., in the store of D Hagerty, (late Hagerty & Starke,) No. 200 Main street, is offered for sale at cost to close business.
Persons in want of any article in this line, will find it to their advantage to call and supply themselves.
[no 24--ts]V. Bargamin.
Trustee.

div3.head: Virginia and Tennessee Railroad Coupons.
div3.p: --The holders of the Interest Coupons of the first and second mortgages of this Company, due in New York 1st January, 1861, are hereby notified that they will be cashed on presentation at my office, on and after this date, without discount for pre payment.
F. G. Morrison,
no 25--t1stJ Treas'r Va, and Tenn R R Co.

div3.head: Save your Dimes,
div3.p:
--The United Savings Bank will receive at their Office, No. 93 Main street. Deposits in sums of Five Dollars and upwards, upon which will be allowed interest at the rate of 6 per cent per annum if allowed to remain 6 months and 5 per cent for a shorter period.
Interest payable semi-annually.
Jno. C. Page.Jr., Treasurer
oc 3--t1stJan. No. 93 Main street.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --No person whatsoever is authorized to purchase or make any contract for any article for the Spotswood Hotel, or Columbian Hotel unless the same be paid for at the time of delivery.

This publication is not in consequence of anything that has transpired, but to protect me in future, and because of my determination to be constantly posted with regard to the expenditures of both hotels Joseph.
H. Crenshaw.
no 25--1aw3m

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Delinquent Stockholders in the Richmond, Williamsburg and Central Turnpike Company are hereby notified that unless the respective amounts due on their shares shall have been paid by or on the 9th day of December next, the same will be sold at auction, to the highest bidder, on the 1st Monday thereafter (if fair; if not, on the next fair day,) at 5 P. M., at the Company's Toll Gate.
no 10--law4w by order of the Board.

div3.head: Timber for sale.
div3.p:
--The advertiser has for sale a lot of Timber upon about a hundred acres of land.
The Timber consists of White Oak, suitable for ship timber or staves.
Red Oak fit for staves or fuel; and Chesnut, which makes the best of fencing stuff.
This timber lies about three miles from a wharf on the Chickahominy River.
For further information refer to Logan Waller, Esq., Richmond, Va.
no 14--1aw2m

div3.head: [from the London times, November 9th]
div3.p:
Victor Emmanuel King of Neptes King Victor Emmanuel has accepted the sovereignty of Italy.
He must have had strict but, notions of etiquette if he had any longer hesitated.
He, who has disregarded so many right, who has evaded international law and thrown to the winds international courtesy, who has bearded an Emperor and a Pope, who has several brother sovereigns out of their intones, who is banded with revolutionists, and it at this moment virtually excommunicated, need hardly be deterred from calling himself King because his discrowned still on ground, Should the fortune of war, of that obstinacy which underlies such characters as that of Francis 11, cause the detente of Greta to be prolonged, it is all the better that the impatience of the and finish now subjects should get the better of diplomatic ceremony, and that Vic or Emmanuel should have given effect to the premise by proclaiming himself King.--The who has not been stopped by the remanence of half Europe and by the threats of , must not back before a formula. That there cannot be two bishops came is an old , and yet there been the of expeded prelates, p , and eye Popes. S., for a few days, there will be two Kings actually exercising royal authority the same rea. The N must make up their minds to be for a to a divided allegiance, and to be traitors to the King de facto, or the King de jure A. Victor Emmanuel will, at any rate, have to annex some of the Papal provinces while the Pope is still at Rome, there was really no reason why he should treat his rival of Naples with greater consideration — After what has taken place, friends would have been included to smile and enemies to sneer at any further display of scrupulosity.

The fabric of B despotism was met overtown by the tempest, and is now being submerged by the tide.
Ever nearer and nearer , carrying a way each day some out which remained.
The latest incidents are the liking of Corpus, the entrance to the new King into Naples, and the assumption of the offered crown.
The latter deserves to be recorded as an event of interest, though it can hardly be said to have much importance on the result of the war. It will seize the popular imagination, and an excitable folly like the Neapolitan will probably pass into ecstasies of loyalty, which will extend themselves throughout the country.
In so far as the attachment of the people and the demonstrations watch they make are likely to strengthen Victor Emmanuel in Europe, we rejoice at the reception he met with me, on Wednesday morning, he entered that fair city, the pride of Italy and the admiration of strangers, now destined to be one of the capitals of a great and powerful monarchy, Although rain fell in currents, the people turned out in enthusiastic crowd, to Welcome their new sovereign.

Victor Emmanuel appeared among them, not is a conqueror, or as the representative of foreign domination, but as a King Italian born and which I alien sympathies, who, during many years of almost difficult reign, has un-awaringly pursued the same course, and struggled for the independence of his country in the field and in the council chamber --As the King passed through their streets amid the of thousands, amid the acclamation of lazziroul, who a few months ago were ready with noisy demonstrations of loyalty to the worst of tyrants, the more educated spectators must have felt the greatness of the triumph and the completeness of the lesson.
There were among them, doubtless, many whose rises were still galled by Boubou handcuff.
whose eyes were weak by long hesitation to darkness, whose lungs were asthmatic through the stench of prisons, whose frames were weak from years of insufficient food, whose backs, perhaps, were scarred by the lash.
Other and more horrible outrages might be recorded by some of those who stood to see the saviour of their country and the future defender of its liberties enter the city which has been so gallantly won for him. To such men the events of the present year must seem like a dream, so rapid, astonishing, and complete has been the over throw of the race which persecuted them In this moment of joy they must have been inclined to view all things favorably; and yet it requires some pretence and some knowledge of mankind to reconcile us to the conversion of the Neapolitan multitude.

The patriots who, like Poerlo, suffered for their efforts to center liberty on the people of Southern Italy, must remember that this people saw them go to their dungeons without a murmur, almost without a thought; that for ten years they lingered in misery while Napoleon, drank, danced sung slept as usual; and that it is only when the b of a distant province, headed by a band adventurer, drive the tyrants from their houses, that they venture to raise their voice against oppression which to noble spirits was worse than death.
Then, indeed, they raise their voices high enough, and show more loudly for the soldiers of liberty than ever they did for the dull line of despots who are gone.
As the cries of the gesticulating and frenzied crowds rose along the King the excited, upturned continuances watched his progress, the martyrs of liberally must have thought with a little bitterness how great a is success, which can transfer the affections and trans the

But, it the enthusiasm of Naples be not an offering of her higher class, if the loyalty of this and impulsive race follow the strongest battalions and the most determined policy, so much the more credit is due to the ruler, the statesman, and the soldiers who have insured success to the cause of liberty.
We have always thought that in these Italian affairs the opportunities have been made by the men rather than the men by the opportunities.
Italy owes everything to the policy and the converge of Victor Emmanuel, Civour, and Girinaldi.
have of the Austrian, no vague yearning after nationality, collapses towards unity, would have advanced the country one step toward it's ends, had not been for the bold minster who established free institutions in one little State, who took a part in the concerns of Europe in 1855 and who, without rashness or blustering, opposed the pretensions of Austria during his noble reign.
It was Victor Emmanuel, the worker of ten years, the constitutional King between the two despotic Empires, the restorer of Italian armies to an independent action in Europe, the party to the important Treaty of Paris, whom educated Neapolitans will cheer.
While the crowd honor the present success and bow down to power however obtained, those who have known how to oppose with success and power will join with them for once in honoring the courageous State.
Sardinia and its wise and politic Government.

I must gratify every one to observe that the divided Garibaldi from the King's advisor it seems to have been quieted forever — The Dictator is also been joining in the festivities which follow victory, and has presented the soldiers with colors, in a speech which breathes nothing but devotion to the cause of Italy and to the Monarch whom she has chosen.
The authority or Victor Emmanuel is by this time Italy established throughout the country, except in the two for tresses which still hold out for the Bourbon.
All the objectionable appointments have been canceled; join the Racialists and the Ultra Democrats have been ; all danger from insulted or from anarchy is at an end, and the two Sicilians are as completely and regularly governed by the new King as if the throne had descended to him through twenty generalists of ancestors.
Victor Emmanuel is now King from the Alps to Sicily.

An official proclamation has annexed the Bouldon kingdom to the happy provinces which are now united under the empire of Sivoy.
Next will come the turn of the Roman States.
There, also, the issue cannot be doubtful.
In every district where French bayonets do not keep the people from the ballot-box the hateful sway of the Pope will be repudiated, and all classes will hasted to transfer their allegiance to the King of Italy.
The only their is just disturbances may arise through the indignation of the people in the garrisoned provinces.
An inhabitant of Rome, or Civitan Vecenia, or Vileth, may be goaded to some rash act by the knowledge that, while his m fortunate country men are electing a constitutional Sovereign, he and his neighbors are forced to remain the slaves of an ecclesiastical rule, to be taxed for the army which oppresses them, to be subject to the outrages of German Condottiere, or spectators of the rioting of flubby Irishmen.
We sincerely hope that the influence of this country will be exerted to rescue as large a portion as possible of the people of the Roman States from this unhappy doom.
We have always thought that the city of Rome and a few miles of the Compagna are quite sufficient heritage for the Popes, and that even then care should be taken to give the Romans municipal institutions, something to those which exist in Hamburg and the other German free towns.--Should such a policy be carried out, nothing will remain out to salute Victor Emmanuel as the first King of Italy, and to wish him and his new realm prosperity and happiness.

div3.head: Notice to the public!
div3.p: --New and important Arrangement, 1860.--The Adams Express Company respectfully announce to the public that they have arranged to run their Express Twice Daily from New York Philadelphia and Baltimore to Richmond, thereby affording unusual facilities for obtaining their freight and packages in the shortest possible time.

Expresses leave New York at 1.5 and 6 o'clock P M Expresses leave Philadelphia at 8 A M and 11 P. M. Expresses leave Baltimore at 4.20 A. M and 4.20 P. M., arriving in Richmond at 3.30 A. M. and 2 P. M
Expresses leave Richmond for New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore, and all points North and West, at 6.30 A. M. and 6.30 P. M.
Freight and packages should in all cases be at our office one hour before the departure of the Trains.
Expresses for the South leave Richmond Twice Daily, at 4.30 A. M. and 2.45 P. M

The Adams Express Company feel that they car guarantee to the public civility, attention and satisfaction in all their intercourse with their officers in Richmond, and nothing will be left undone or their part to meet the wants of their customers.

Freight and packages arriving by the Express from the North at 8 o'clock P. M. will be delivered immediately, thereby giving to our customers an advance of twelve hours over our arrangements heretofore.

Steamer Expresses, to and from New York Semi Weekly.
Freights delivered immediately upon the arrival of the ship,
heavy and Light Freights, Packages, money, Bonds, Legal Documents, &c. forwarded with safety and dispatch to all parts of the United States, Canada and Europe.
